Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Paleotopography using Clumped Isotopes in the Basin and Range: Refining the Three Dimensional Evolution of a Continental Extensional Province
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Basin and Range province of the western United States is perhaps the best exposed and most accessible example of an intracontinental extensional province on Earth today. Although a variety of lines of geological and geophysical evidence indicate that this region has experienced approximately 200% east-west extension since middle Miocene time, the Basin and Range is underlain today by continental crust of typical (30 km) thickness, but that lies at an average elevation (1-1.5 km) substantially higher than one would expect based on simple geophysical calculations. How the continental crust of the Basin and Range has evolved throughout Cenozoic time to have the characteristics that it has today is an outstanding question that bears directly on the nature of diffuse continental deformation, far away from plate boundaries, and the processes that lead the crust to stretch and thin without rupturing to create new oceanic basins. A variety of tectonic models have been invoked to explain the evolution of the Basin and Range, but the geologic observations that would allow one to discriminate between these models are unresolved. One potential discriminant between these models is the predictions each makes for the paleoelevation history of the western United States. Recent advances in the development of paleo-thermometers, using clumped isotopes in lacustrine carbonates, offers a new approach to determining paleotemperatures from the geologic record, and thus, indirectly the paleoelevations at which the carbonates formed. By applying these new methods to measure the temperature differences between a suite of low-elevation, near sea-level lacustrine carbonates, and coeval lacustrine carbonates in the Basin and Range, this project will develop new constraints on the temporal and spatial evolution of topography across the Basin and Range throughout its Cenozoic evolution, and thus address several key questions about the tectonic evolution of the Basin and Range, including: (1) Was the Basin and Range a high-standing plateau prior to extension?; (2) What was the spatial extent of such a plateau, if it existed?; (3) How did the elevation of the Basin and Range change during late Cenozoic extension?; and (4) What processes accommodated large-magnitude extension in late Cenozoic time?

This research will be incorporated into an education and outreach program directed at early middle-school-aged students in the Greater Detroit area through the development and production of a full-dome planetarium movie on plate tectonics, in collaboration with the Exhibit Museum of Natural History and the 3DLabs at the University of Michigan. Early in middle school is the time when many students begin to lose interest in science. This educational project will incorporate the research data gathered from this project, along with the wealth of geological and geophysical data being collected from other ongoing NSF projects, such as Earthscope, into a fully immersive film on the history of the Earth, the processes that drive plate tectonics, the hazards associated with plate boundaries, and the technology we can apply to study modern plate motions. This movie will be incorporated into outreach days on earth sciences at the Exhibit Museum, which reach 3,000-6,000 students annually, and which are designed to get students to think of science as an active and evolving field of study. By developing new and engaging ways of presenting earth science that demonstrate the elements of excitement of discovery and societal relevance that draw in so many who study the earth, the project aims to increase the participation of students in STEM subjects through middle school and beyond.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objective of this project was to use a relatively new technique, clumped isotope analysis, to understand the height of the Earth?s surface across the western United States over the past ~50 million years. The technique relies on the analysis of ?clumping? of rare, or heavy, isotopes in the same molecule of calcium carbonate. Calcium carbonate is a common geological material, found in limestone deposited in ancient lakes, in the shells of animals that live in lakes and streams, and in ancient, fossil soils. The frequency with which heavy isotopes ?clump? together into the same molecule of calcium carbonate is dependent on temperature, and through measuring this clumping, one can potentially determine the temperature of a lake, stream, or soil in the past through the geologic record that it leaves behind (a sample?s clumped isotope temperature).  Because temperature of air and water on the surface of the Earth is strongly linked to elevation, with colder temperatures at higher elevations, this approach also provides a means of exploring how the elevation of Earth?s surface has changed through time, by analyzing the ?clumping? of isotopes in geologic materials of different ages.

Understanding the history of topography and elevation change in the western United States is a critical part of unraveling it?s tectonic evolution.  Fossils and rocks deposited below sea level more than 80 million years ago are now found throughout the present-day Rocky Mountains; ancient lakes that once were home to alligators existed throughout southwestern Wyoming, and a formidable mountain range that once ran through Nevada, Utah, and Arizona has been slowly lowered and pulled apart by the stretching of the western US arising from plate tectonic motions and the formation of the Basin and Range.

One challenge with applying the clumped technique to geologic materials is understanding for how long, and under what conditions, does the original clumped frequency, representing the temperature at which the original sediment was deposited, or fossil lived, persist? Can this temperature be reset by later heating, or burial underneath younger geological layers? Does such alteration place limits on how deep in time that we can probe past surface conditions and elevations? A major aim of this project was to test the limits of preservation of clumped isotope signals in geologic materials, and to better understand which geologic materials and conditions are best suited for preserving past surface temperature information.

We made a major effort in this project to investigate the conditions under which clumped isotope temperatures are preserved by using samples from natural rock exposures in Wyoming and Colorado, as well as from drill core collected from a 5-km-deep borehole in Wyoming. Samples from these sites spanned a range of geologic ages, and variations in depth of burial, and thus degree and duration of heating. We used independent geologic methods, and instrumental measurements from the borehole, to reconstruct the hottest temperatures that the samples we collected had experienced, and how long the samples were exposed to temperatures. We then tested a series of models of how clumped isotope temperature change with burial and heating to predict the conditions under which the original surface clumped isotope temperatures are preserved. We found that samples buried and heated to temperatures of <~100?C retain temperatures that appear to be indistinguishable from their original surface temperatures. As samples are buried to greater depths (and hotter temperatures), the clumped isotope temperature slowly transforms to reflect the burial temperature of the sample, with greater transformation at hotter temperatures.  Our results suggest that clumped isotope temperatures can be used to understand surface temperatures in the geologic past, but only under conditions in which the samples were not deeply buried or heated after formation.

We were also able to make determinations of the temperature at the surface of the Earth in southwestern Wyoming approximately 40 million years ago from our clumped isotope analysis. These data suggest that Wyoming was much warmer than it is today, and that such warmer temperatures were likely due to both changes in elevation and long-term fluctuations in climate since that time.

This project provided training to a postdoctoral scholar, a PhD students, and a MS student, and resulted in the creation of an educational film on plate tectonics, designed for projection in a planetarium dome, that has been used for outreach and education at the University of Michigan Museum of Natural History at the elementary school level.
